title: Assessment of Mechanical and Non Destructive Properties of Heavy Density Concrete Subjected to Acid Attack
abstract: Heavy-density concrete plays a pivotal role in providing structural integrity and radiation shielding in critical infrastructure. However, exposure to acidic environments poses a significant challenge, potentially compromising the material's durability and mechanical properties. This research examines the mechanical and non-destructive properties of heavy-density concrete produced by integrating grit iron scale aggregates as coarse aggregate in concrete and the utilization of silica fume as a supplementary cementitious material. The experiments involve preparing samples using 25% and 50% Heavy Weight Grit Iron Scale (HWGS) Aggregate along with 15% silica fume. Concrete specimens were tested for slump, compressive strength and rebound hammer after 28 days of curing. The water-cured specimens were exposed to 10% of sulfuric acid (H2SO4). The findings indicated that concrete containing 25% HWGS exhibited superior acid resistance in comparison to the other concrete mixes while achieving maximum compressive strength.
authors: Mohammad Jamal Khattak, Sedra Tul Muntaha, Kinaan Sultan Khan Niazi, Yasir Rasheed
summary: Heavy-density concrete is vital for infrastructure but its durability is significantly challenged by acidic environments. This study investigated improving heavy-density concrete by integrating grit iron scale aggregates and silica fume, examining its mechanical properties and acid resistance. Samples with varying percentages of grit iron scale (25% and 50%) and 15% silica fume were tested for strength and then exposed to sulfuric acid. The findings indicated that concrete containing 25% grit iron scale aggregates demonstrated superior acid resistance and achieved maximum compressive strength.

title: Guided wave localization and quantification of actual corrosion damage in metallic pipelines considering environmental factors
abstract: Abstract Corrosion damage is a primary cause of pipeline failure, and guided waves are conventionally employed for non-destructive testing purposes. However, the intricacy of authentic corrosion damage and environmental factors (EFs) complicate the quantitative evaluation of corrosion damage by guided waves. In this paper, four metal pipes with different degrees of corrosion were prepared by accelerated corrosion experiments over a period of 30 days, and a guided wave localization method for pipeline corrosion damage considering EFs and a corrosion degree quantification method based on the change of guided wave velocity are proposed. These methods utilize the interaction between the propagation characteristics of guided waves and corrosion damage, while taking into account the interference caused by EFs, and reduce the influence of EFs on the localization and quantitative assessment of corrosion damage by extracting features that are sensitive to corrosion damage. The experimental findings demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed method in achieving precise corrosion damage location and quantitative assessment of the degree of corrosion. The relative errors in corrosion damage location and quantitative assessment were found to be 6.28% and 9.38%, respectively. The methods provided in this paper offer new solutions for the detection of corrosion damage in metallic pipelines in real engineering.
authors: Yanqi Wang, Tao Zhou, Zhiyuan Zhang, Tianyi Xiao, Yuelong Wang, Bing Li
summary: Pipeline corrosion damage is a major cause of failure, and conventional guided wave non-destructive testing faces challenges in quantitative evaluation due to complex corrosion and environmental factors. This paper introduces novel guided wave methods for localizing and quantifying pipeline corrosion, which effectively mitigate environmental interference by extracting corrosion-sensitive features. Developed through accelerated corrosion experiments, these methods demonstrated high precision, achieving relative errors of 6.28% for localization and 9.38% for quantitative assessment, thus offering practical solutions for real-world pipeline inspection.

title: Research on the Hyperspectral-based Unmixing Model of Composite Pigments on Mural Surfaces
abstract: Abstract. Murals constitute an invaluable component of cultural heritage, encapsulating profound artistic and historical significance. Hyperspectral remote sensing, as a non-destructive testing technique, offers an effective means for analysing and identifying mural pigments. We proposed a spectral unmixing method based on the negative logarithm of spectral reflectance, aimed at improving the accuracy of quantitative analysis for composite pigments in murals. We obtained three sets of mixed spectra: cinnabar-orpiment, azurite-orpiment, and azurite-malachite. The original reflectance was converted into negative logarithmic values, and linear models were applied for unmixing. Supervised unmixing was conducted in the experiment to evaluate the model’s precision, with the unmixing process carried out using known endmembers. The unmixing accuracy was quantified using the Root Mean Square Error, which compares the estimated abundances of all endmembers with actual values. Additionally, a comparison was made between the negative logarithmic transformation and the commonly used transformations of original reflectance, first derivative, and second derivative. The result show that the logarithmic hyperspace linear model simplifies spectral unmixing complexity, enhancing the accuracy of linear unmixing models in addressing mixed pigment unmixing problems. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed method for real murals, the improved model was applied to the hyperspectral data unmixing analysis of murals collected by the Yungang Academy, located in Shanxi Province, China. Experimental findings demonstrate that, compared to traditional methods, the improved unmixing approach more precisely represents the pigment distribution in the murals. This study offers new ideas and methods for the digital preservation and restoration of mural composite pigments.
authors: Yihan Zhang, Shuqiang Lyu, Miaole Hou, Jing Guo, Junlin Yan
summary: This study presents a novel hyperspectral spectral unmixing method for analyzing composite pigments in culturally significant murals. The method converts original reflectance into negative logarithmic values, aiming to improve the accuracy of quantitative pigment analysis. Experimental results show that this logarithmic transformation simplifies unmixing complexity and significantly enhances the precision of linear unmixing models compared to traditional approaches. Applied to real mural data, the improved method more accurately represents pigment distribution, offering new ideas for digital preservation and restoration.

title: Deep Residual Learning for Hyperspectral Imaging Camouflage Detection with SPXY-Optimized Feature Fusion Framework
abstract: Camouflage detection in hyperspectral images remains challenging due to the high spectral similarity between artificial materials and natural vegetation. This study aimed to develop a non-destructive classification framework for distinguishing camouflage fabrics from natural grass based on reflectance data within the 389.06-1005.10 nm range. The workflow involved Principal Component Analysis (PCA) performed using ENVI software for dimensionality reduction, followed by Standard Normal Variate (SNV) transformation, Savitzky–Golay(SG) filtering, first-order derivative processing, and Z-score normalization. The Sample set Partitioning based on joint X-Y distance (SPXY) algorithm was utilized to enhance sample representativeness. Six classification models were constructed, including PCA, Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), and Residual Neural Network (ResNet). The SPXY-ResNet model achieved the highest classification performance, with an accuracy of 99.17%, a precision of 98.89%, a recall of 98.82%, and an F1-score of 98.82%. Model calibration under different sampling strategies was evaluated using Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence, mean similarity, and standard deviation of similarity. Results indicated that the SPXY algorithm improved distributional consistency between training and testing sets, thereby enhancing generalization performance. The confusion matrix revealed only two misclassifications among 120 test samples, indicating strong classification reliability. Convergence curves further confirmed stable training behavior, with no signs of overfitting. These results demonstrate that the proposed SPXY-ResNet framework offers accurate and robust performance for camouflage detection in complex spectral environments.
authors: Qiran Wang, Jinshi Cui
summary: This study developed a non-destructive classification framework to distinguish camouflage fabrics from natural grass using hyperspectral reflectance data, addressing challenges posed by high spectral similarity. The methodology involved extensive data pre-processing and the Sample set Partitioning based on joint X-Y distance (SPXY) algorithm to enhance sample representativeness. Among six evaluated classification models, the SPXY-ResNet model achieved the highest classification performance, demonstrating an accuracy of 99.17% with strong reliability. This proposed SPXY-ResNet framework offers an accurate and robust solution for camouflage detection in complex spectral environments, with the SPXY algorithm improving generalization.

title: The current research status of non-destructive testing technologies for egg quality: internal freshness – a review
abstract: 1. Traditional methods of assessing egg freshness, such as sensory evaluation and specific gravity testing, are labour-intensive and destructive. However, non-destructive testing (NDT) technologies offer significant advantages in terms of speed, accuracy and non-invasiveness, enabling real-time monitoring of egg quality during production, transportation, storage and sale.
authors: Zhaohong Shi, Wenhui Zhu, Yu Qiao, Q. Li, Binyu Pan, Feng Zhang, Chaojie Wang, Juan Bai, Li Sun, Jie Cai
summary: Traditional methods for assessing egg freshness are inefficient, requiring significant labor and often damaging the eggs. In contrast, non-destructive testing (NDT) technologies offer a superior alternative due to their speed, accuracy, and non-invasive nature. These technologies enable continuous, real-time monitoring of egg quality across all stages, from production to sale.

title: Introduction of Microbottle Resonator for Honey Concentration Sensing
abstract: This paper investigates the behaviour of whispering gallery modes (WGMs) in a silica-based micro bottle resonator (MBR) for honey concentration sensing. The MBR was fabricated using the soften-and-compress technique on standard SMF-28 silica fibre, creating a bottle-shaped structure with controlled bottle diameter, stem diameter, and bottle length. A tapered microfiber with a 2 µm waist diameter was used for coupling, enabling the resonator to achieve a high quality factor (Q > 1.5×10⁵), confirming its low-loss performance and strong field confinement. Honey samples with concentrations ranging from 10% to 60% were analysed. The MBR sensor demonstrated a sensitivity of 0.0824 dB/% with excellent linearity of 97%, while wavelength-shift analysis showed an additional sensitivity of 4.0 pm/%. The sensor exhibited stable and repeatable responses across multiple experimental cycles and short-term stability tests. Compared with conventional techniques such as refractometry, FTIR, and electrochemical methods, the MBR offers significant advantages in compactness, non-destructive measurement, and sensitivity. These findings establish the MBR as a reliable platform for honey quality monitoring and authenticity testing, with potential for broader food and industrial sensing applications.
authors: Sharifah Mohamad, Mohd Nor Zamani bin Abdul Afri, Md Ashadi Md Johari, N. Khalid
summary: This paper investigates the use of a silica-based micro bottle resonator (MBR) and its whispering gallery modes (WGMs) for sensing honey concentration. Fabricated from standard optical fiber, the MBR achieved a high quality factor, indicating strong field confinement and low loss when coupled with a tapered microfiber. Testing honey samples from 10% to 60% concentration, the sensor demonstrated high sensitivity (0.0824 dB/% and 4.0 pm/%) with excellent linearity and stable, repeatable responses. These findings establish the MBR as a compact, non-destructive, and sensitive platform, making it a promising tool for honey quality monitoring and broader food and industrial sensing applications.

title: INDT-YOLOV11 detection model based on variable space pooling denoising for rapid identification of bubbles and delamination
abstract: Abstract Internal defects such as bubbles and delamination in 3D-printed carbon fiber composite components severely compromise the mechanical properties of these components. Infrared thermography is an effective technique for detecting internal defects in materials. However, traditional detection methods depend on manual inspection, which suffers from several limitations, including low efficiency, relatively high false detection rates, and slow processing speed. These shortcomings hinder their ability to meet the demands of industrial applications. This study proposes an model of Infrared Non-destructive Testing - You Only Look Once V11(INDT-YOLOV11 )rapid object detection model. Based on YOLOV11n, we present a VSP-C3k2 module incorporating variant spatial pooling to mitigate noise interference during feature fusion. The SaE mechanism from SENetV2 is integrated with the C2PSA module to form a SaE-C2PSA attention mechanism, enhancing defect feature representation. To improve detection speed, the original backbone network in YOLOV11n is replaced with a MobileNetV2 feature extraction network. A dataset containing bubbles and delamination defects was established using Infrared Non-destructive Testing(INDT) based on halogen lamp to capture infrared thermal images. Experimental results demonstrate that compared with YOLOV11n, the proposed INDT-YOLOV11 model achieves 20.85% and 20.75% improvements in mAP50 and mAP50-90 metrics respectively, while reducing parameter count and computational load by approximately 38.59% and 39.06%. On GTX1050 hardware, INDT-YOLOV11 achieves 31.5 FPS with 23.05% speed enhancement. And INDT-YOLOV11 has achieved almost the same mAP50 as YOLOV8-worldv2 and YOLOX lightweight models with minimal parameter and computational complexity, making it highly competitive in models such as YOLO-SA，providing effective technical support for automated internal defect detection in 3D-printed carbon fiber composite components.
authors: Jianing Ning Zhang, Fengxia Han, Hongjun Wang
summary: Internal defects like bubbles and delamination severely compromise the mechanical properties of 3D-printed carbon fiber composites, yet traditional infrared thermography detection methods are inefficient and slow for industrial applications. This study proposes INDT-YOLOV11, a rapid object detection model for automated infrared non-destructive testing of these components. The model integrates a VSP-C3k2 module for noise reduction, a SaE-C2PSA attention mechanism to enhance defect feature representation, and a MobileNetV2 backbone for improved detection speed. Experimental results demonstrate that INDT-YOLOV11 significantly boosts detection accuracy and speed while reducing computational load, providing effective technical support for automated internal defect detection.

title: Robust Industrial Surface Defect Detection Using Statistical Feature Extraction and Capsule Network Architectures
abstract: Automated quality control is critical in modern manufacturing, especially for metallic cast components, where fast and accurate surface defect detection is required. This study evaluates classical Machine Learning (ML) algorithms using extracted statistical parameters and deep learning (DL) architectures including ResNet50, Capsule Networks, and a 3D Convolutional Neural Network (CNN3D) using 3D image inputs. Using the Dataset Original, ML models with the selected parameters achieved high performance: RF reached 99.4 ± 0.2% precision and 99.4 ± 0.2% sensitivity, GB 96.0 ± 0.2% precision and 96.0 ± 0.2% sensitivity. ResNet50 trained with extracted parameters reached 98.0 ± 1.5% accuracy and 98.2 ± 1.7% F1-score. Capsule-based architectures achieved the best results, with ConvCapsuleLayer reaching 98.7 ± 0.2% accuracy and 100.0 ± 0.0% precision for the normal class, and 98.9 ± 0.2% F1-score for the affected class. CNN3D applied on 3D image inputs reached 88.61 ± 1.01% accuracy and 90.14 ± 0.95% F1-score. Using the Dataset Expanded with ML and PCA-selected features, Random Forest achieved 99.4 ± 0.2% precision and 99.4 ± 0.2% sensitivity, K-Nearest Neighbors 99.2 ± 0.0% precision and 99.2 ± 0.0% sensitivity, and SVM 99.2 ± 0.0% precision and 99.2 ± 0.0% sensitivity, demonstrating consistent high performance. All models were evaluated using repeated train-test splits to calculate averages of standard metrics (accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score), and processing times were measured, showing very low per-image execution times (as low as 3.69×10−4 s/image), supporting potential real-time industrial application. These results indicate that combining statistical descriptors with ML and DL architectures provides a robust and scalable solution for automated, non-destructive surface defect detection, with high accuracy and reliability across both the original and expanded datasets.
authors: Azeddine Mjahad, Alfredo Rosado-Muñoz
summary: This study investigated automated surface defect detection for metallic cast components using both classical Machine Learning (ML) algorithms with statistical parameters and various Deep Learning (DL) architectures. Models including Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, ResNet50, Capsule Networks, and a 3D CNN were evaluated on original and expanded 3D image datasets. Classical ML models and Capsule Networks achieved particularly high performance, with precision and sensitivity often exceeding 99%. Crucially, all evaluated models demonstrated very low processing times, suggesting their strong potential for robust, scalable, and real-time industrial quality control applications.

title: An electro-optical bunch profile monitor for FCC-ee
abstract: The Future Circular Lepton Collider (FCC-ee) presents challenges for a longitudinal bunch profile monitor due to its wide range of bunch lengths and charge densities across its four distinct operational modes. For commissioning, monitoring the top-up injection, and energy calibration, the FCC-ee requires non-destructive, single-shot measurements of the bunch length and profile. This contribution proposes an in-vacuum electro-optical (EO) longitudinal bunch profile monitor for single-shot measurements at high repetition rates, building on the successful EO monitor at the Karlsruhe Research Accelerator (KARA) at the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology. A novel single-pass conceptual design for the in-vacuum holder of the electro-optical crystal is presented, utilizing prisms instead of a mirror to guide the laser through the crystal, which additionally allows measurements of the long bunches foreseen for FCC-ee operation mode at the Z-pole energy. A first prototype has been constructed and tested at the in-air test stand of the CERN Linear Electron Accelerator for Research (CLEAR). Results from the prototype tests are presented, demonstrating the proof of principle for the single-pass prism-based EO monitor design for FCC-ee.
authors: Magdalena Reissig, Erik Bründermann, Stefan Funkner, Laura A. Grimm, Bastian Härer, Gudrun Niehues, Johannes Steinmann, Anke-Susanne Müller, Rachel Corsini, Antonio Gilardi, S. Mazzoni, C. Pakuza, Andreas Schloegelhofer, T. Lefevre, Pierre Korysko
summary: The Future Circular Lepton Collider (FCC-ee) requires a non-destructive, single-shot monitor for its longitudinal electron bunch profile, essential for commissioning, injection, and energy calibration across its diverse operational modes. This work proposes an in-vacuum electro-optical (EO) monitor, featuring a novel single-pass design that utilizes prisms to guide the laser through the crystal. This prism-based approach specifically enables the measurement of the long bunches expected during FCC-ee's Z-pole energy operation. A prototype of this design was successfully constructed and tested, demonstrating the proof of principle for this innovative EO monitor for FCC-ee applications.

title: Nondestructive testing of prestressed ground anchors using ultrasonics: theory, simulation, and experiments
abstract: Prestressed ground anchors have been widely used in numerous slopes to prevent slope failure. However, the inevitable loss of prestress can affect the long-term operational safety of slopes in the field of prevention and control engineering. This study analysed the deterioration of the external anchor head and its main causes based on a field investigation, and a theoretical model for the non-destructive testing (NDT) of prestressed slope anchors using ultrasonics was derived. Subsequently, the stress and displacement distribution characteristics of the anchor head were analysed by numerical simulation. Two ultrasonic sensors (2.5 MHz and 5.0 MHz) were employed to test the prestress of the anchor, and a relationship between the energy and prestress was established. The results showed that the prestress can be determined by analysing the reflection waves, the energy of which decreased nonlinearly with increasing load, and the energy – prestress relationship could be well fitted using an exponential function. The 2.5 MHz ultrasonic sensor outperformed the 5.0 MHz ultrasonic sensor, and the third reflection wave (RW3) exhibited the highest stability and best fitting, making it suitable for establishing the relationship between the energy and prestress of the ground anchor. This study provides references for the NDT of prestressed ground anchors.
authors: Weiming He, Qiang Cai, Zhaoqun Jiang, Hang-Tian Zhang
summary: Prestressed ground anchors are crucial for slope stability, but their long-term safety is compromised by inevitable prestress loss. This study developed a non-destructive testing (NDT) method using ultrasonics to assess prestress in these anchors, involving field investigation, theoretical modeling, and numerical simulation. Experimental testing with 2.5 MHz and 5.0 MHz ultrasonic sensors established a relationship between reflection wave energy and prestress. The findings indicate that prestress can be accurately determined from reflection wave energy, which decreases nonlinearly with load, with the 2.5 MHz sensor and the third reflection wave (RW3) showing the most stable and accurate results.

title: Beam Tracking X-Ray Phase-Contrast Imaging Using a Conventional X-Ray Source
abstract: To address the issue of insufficient contrast in conventional X-ray absorption imaging for biological soft tissues and weakly absorbing materials, this paper proposes a beam tracking X-ray phase-contrast imaging system using a conventional X-ray source. A periodic pinhole array mask is placed between the X-ray source and the sample to spatially modulate the X-ray beam, dividing it into multiple independent sub-beams. Each sub-beam is deflected due to the modulation effect of the sample, resulting in slight positional shifts in the intensity patterns formed on the detector. The experiments employ an X-ray source with a 400 μm focal spot and use a two-dimensional step-scanning approach to acquire image sequences of various samples. The experimental results show that this method can extract the edge profile and structural changes in the samples to some extent, and it demonstrates good contrast and detail recovery under weak absorption conditions. These results suggest that this method has certain application potential in material inspection, non-destructive testing, and related fields.
authors: Jiaqi Li, Jianheng Huang, Xin Liu, Yaohu Lei, B. Mai, Chenggong Zhang
summary: This paper proposes a beam tracking X-ray phase-contrast imaging system to address the low contrast of conventional X-ray imaging for soft tissues and weakly absorbing materials. The system employs a conventional X-ray source and a pinhole array to create multiple sub-beams, which are then deflected by the sample, causing detectable positional shifts. Experiments show that this method effectively extracts edge profiles and structural changes, demonstrating good contrast and detail recovery even under weak absorption conditions. These findings suggest the method's potential for applications in material inspection and non-destructive testing.

title: Shell Quality Parameters of Japanese Quail (Coturnix japonica) Eggs as Estimated by Non‐Destructive Testing Technology
abstract: ABSTRACT The quality parameters of quail eggshells find extensive utility in studies of production efficiency and basic biology. Non‐destructive evaluation methods are of particular relevance. Herein, we developed a non‐destructive technology for assaying such shell characteristics as shell strength ( F ), thickness ( T ), and weight ( W s ). Studies were conducted using 176 eggs laid by 11‐month‐old quails from a resource population of F 2 crossbreds. The main set of measured and calculated parameters included egg weight ( W ), volume ( V ), and surface area ( S ). In addition, we determined an indicator of elastic shell deformation under a non‐destructive load of 0.5 kg ( δ 0.5 ). Use of this parameter set allowed us to make the most accurate non‐invasive prediction of the values of F ( R = 0.756), T ( R = 0.266), and W s ( R = 0.450) for quail eggs. As a result of comparative analysis of the current and previously obtained equations for calculating W s , the disadvantages of using empirical equations were also identified. Herewith, we proposed the so‐called index approach to forming mathematical dependences, simplifying their further use, for example, in breeding studies. As such, we selected the following conditionally called indices: metabolism index ( S / V ) and specific elastic shell deformation ( δ 0.5 / W ). Following the approximation, more convenient and compact dependences were produced. The correlation coefficients between the true and computed values were 0.749 for predicting F , 0.262 for T , and 0.443 for W s , with corresponding RMSE values equal to 0.416 for F , 0.019 for T , and 0.105 for W s . The established index representation of empirical equations will serve as a crucial instrument for eggshell quality control and application in quail breeding.
authors: Valeriy G. Narushin, Н. А. Волкова, Alan Yu. Dzhagaev, Zarina V. Gagieva, Л. А. Волкова, Darren K. Griffin, Michael N Romanov, N. A. Zinovieva
summary: This study developed a non-destructive method to assess quail eggshell quality parameters, including strength, thickness, and weight, which are crucial for production efficiency and biological research. The technology utilized various egg characteristics, such as elastic deformation under a non-destructive load, to accurately predict these shell properties. Researchers also introduced an innovative "index approach" to simplify the mathematical dependencies for prediction while maintaining comparable accuracy. This new index-based method offers a practical and important tool for eggshell quality control and application in quail breeding programs.

title: Simulation of Inner Wall Eddy Current Test of Electric Multiple Unit Axle
abstract: The axle is an important part of the EMU. If the axle is damaged, it will greatly harm the driving safety, so it is necessary to find out the defects and hidden dangers of the axle in time. At present, the main non-destructive detection methods for the inner wall damage of hollow axle are ultrasonic detection, but this method has the problem of low detection accuracy for the inner wall near the surface of the axle. In order to solve this problem, a cylindrical array eddy current testing method is proposed in this paper. Compared with ultrasonic wave, eddy current generated by alternating electromagnetic field has stronger penetration, so the electromagnetic detection method can solve such problems well. Through modeling and simulation of the damage detection method on the inner wall surface, the detection signal results under different hidden defects are analyzed, and the defects are preliminarily determined. The results show that compared with the traditional ultrasonic detection method, the detection accuracy of this eddy current detection method can be increased to 0.25mm and provide a basis for the follow-up experiment to explore the relationship between the defect characteristics and the signal change law, the hidden defects of the inner wall can be preliminarily estimated in the future.
authors: R.J. Jiang, Xiang Zheng, Haoran Wang
summary: Axle damage in EMUs presents a serious safety hazard, but current ultrasonic detection methods for inner wall defects in hollow axles have low accuracy, especially near the surface. To overcome this, the paper proposes a cylindrical array eddy current testing method, leveraging the stronger penetration of eddy currents compared to ultrasound. Through modeling and simulation, the study demonstrates that this eddy current method significantly improves detection accuracy to 0.25mm, surpassing traditional ultrasonic techniques. These findings provide a foundation for future experimental work to characterize defect features and estimate hidden inner wall defects.

title: PathQC: Determining Molecular and Physical Integrity of Tissues from Histopathological Slides
abstract: Quantifying tissue molecular and physical integrity is essential for biobank development. However, current assessment methods either involve destructive testing that depletes valuable biospecimens or rely on manual evaluations, which are not scalable and lead to interindividual variation. To overcome these challenges, we present PathQC, a deep learning framework that directly predicts the tissue RNA Integrity Number (RIN) and the extent of autolysis from hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained whole-slide images of normal tissue biopsies. PathQC first extracts morphological features from the slide using a recently developed digital pathology foundation model (UNI), followed by a supervised model that learns to predict RNA Integrity Number and autolysis scores from these morphological features. PathQC is trained on and applied to the Genotype-Tissue Expression (GTEx) cohort, which comprises 25,306 non-diseased post-mortem samples across 29 tissues from 970 donors, where paired ground truth RIN and autolysis scores were available. Here, PathQC predicted RIN with an average correlation of 0.47 and an autolysis score of 0.45, with notably high performance in Adrenal Gland tissue (R=0.82) for RIN and in Colon tissue (R=0.83) for autolysis. We provide a pan-tissue model for the prediction of RIN and autolysis score for a new slide from any tissue type. Overall, PathQC will enable scalable measurement of molecular and physical integrity from routine H&E images, thereby enhancing the quality of both biobank generation and its retrospective analysis.
authors: Reema Sinha, Anamika Yadav, Sanju Sinha
summary:
Current methods for assessing tissue integrity are often destructive or lack scalability and consistency. To overcome these limitations, researchers developed PathQC, a deep learning framework that predicts RNA Integrity Number (RIN) and autolysis scores directly from standard hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained whole-slide images. PathQC extracts morphological features using a digital pathology foundation model, followed by a supervised model for prediction.

Trained on over 25,000 non-diseased post-mortem samples from the GTEx cohort, PathQC demonstrated significant predictive capabilities for RIN (average correlation R=0.47) and autolysis (average R=0.45), with notably high performance in specific tissues. This pan-tissue model provides a scalable and non-destructive method for measuring molecular and physical tissue integrity. Ultimately, PathQC will enhance the quality control of biobank generation and facilitate retrospective analyses.

title: Defect Segmentation in OCT scans of ceramic parts for non-destructive inspection using deep learning
abstract: Non-destructive testing (NDT) is essential in ceramic manufacturing to ensure the quality of components without compromising their integrity. In this context, Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) enables high-resolution internal imaging, revealing defects such as pores, delaminations, or inclusions. This paper presents an automatic defect detection system based on Deep Learning (DL), trained on OCT images with manually segmented annotations. A neural network based on the U-Net architecture is developed, evaluating multiple experimental configurations to enhance its performance. Post-processing techniques enable both quantitative and qualitative evaluation of the predictions. The system shows an accurate behavior of 0.979 Dice Score, outperforming comparable studies. The inference time of 18.98 seconds per volume supports its viability for detecting inclusions, enabling more efficient, reliable, and automated quality control.
authors: Andrés Laveda-Martínez, Natalia P. García-de-la-Puente, Fernando García-Torres, Niels Møller Israelsen, Ole Bang, Dominik Brouczek, Niels Benson, Adrián Colomer, Valery Naranjo
summary: This paper presents an automatic defect detection system for ceramic manufacturing, utilizing Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) for high-resolution internal imaging. The system employs a Deep Learning model based on the U-Net architecture, trained on manually annotated OCT images to identify defects like inclusions. Achieving a high accuracy of 0.979 Dice Score, the system outperforms comparable studies and demonstrates a practical inference time of 18.98 seconds per volume. This approach offers a more efficient, reliable, and automated solution for quality control in ceramic components.

title: Limits for Axial Motion in Cone Beam Computed Tomography
abstract: ABSTRACT Computed Tomography (CT) is a technique that allows the non‐destructive evaluation of internal structures of objects, producing cross‐sectional images. In many situations, it is necessary to explore objects with dimensions larger than the tomographic arrangement. To overcome this situation, it is possible to move the elements of the tomographic array and increase the field of view. One strategy with this objective is scanning with axial movement. To reduce exploration times, axial displacements should be as large as possible, ensuring that all the information necessary to reconstruct the volume with all its characteristics is obtained. This work analyzes the limits applicable to axial movement and its relationship with the geometry of the tomographic array. An analytical expression that measures the values of the axial displacement was obtained. The mathematical expression was validated using synthetic data and real images. The results obtained verify the validity of the proposed expression. In test data sets, it was verified that the use of an axial displacement smaller than the calculated limit ensures the reconstruction of the volume, preserving all its information. Using axial displacements larger than the calculated limit results in missing sections of the volume that are not fully captured.
authors: Joel Sánchez Domínguez, Felix Mas Millian, Dany Sánchez Domínguez, Susana Marrero Iglesias, Joaquim Teixeira de Assis
summary: Computed Tomography (CT) is a non-destructive technique, but its limited field of view makes scanning large objects challenging. To overcome this, axial movement of the tomographic array can expand the scanning area. This study analyzes the optimal limits for axial displacement to minimize scanning time while ensuring complete data acquisition for volume reconstruction. An analytical expression was derived and validated, demonstrating that adhering to the calculated displacement limit ensures full data capture, whereas exceeding it leads to incomplete reconstructions with missing sections.

title: Combining 3D Geometric Documentation with Infra-Red Thermography for Enhancing Cultural Heritage
abstract: Abstract. The effective preservation and condition assessment of cultural heritage structures require advanced non-destructive testing (NDT) techniques that can identify structural issues without inflicting harm. This study proposes a novel methodology that integrates Infrared Thermography (IRT) with three-dimensional (3D) geometric documentation to create a comprehensive diagnostic system for heritage conservation. The method was applied to walls adjacent to the Library of Pantainos in the Ancient Agora of Athens, Greece. Geometric documentation was achieved through terrestrial surveying and photogrammetric techniques to generate detailed 3D models. For this purpose, non-destructive testing (NDT) techniques were applied. Specifically Infrared Thermography (IRT), high-resolution infrared thermograms were acquired using a thermal camera under controlled environmental conditions and systematically mapped onto the geometric documentation products, enabling precise localization of thermal anomalies and structural deterioration. In addition, digital microscopy (DM) was also employed to categorize stones and mortars. This combined approach allows for precise localization and visualization of thermal anomalies, such as rising damp, material deterioration, and structural weaknesses. In Wall 1, the method identified rising damp accumulation leading to salt crystallization, while in Walls 2 and 3, severe material degradation and thermal stresses were observed. By integrating interdisciplinary data, this technique enhances the accuracy and efficiency of condition assessments, supporting informed conservation decisions. The study demonstrates the significant potential of combining IRT with 3D documentation to improve diagnostic capabilities and offers a robust framework for future applications in cultural heritage conservation.
authors: Andrianna Kontoudaki, S. Tapinaki, Ekaterini T. Delegou, Kyriakos C. Labropoulos, A. Moropoulou, Andreas Georgopoulos
summary: This study proposes a novel non-destructive methodology for assessing cultural heritage structures, integrating Infrared Thermography (IRT) with three-dimensional (3D) geometric documentation. The method involves generating detailed 3D models using surveying and photogrammetry, then systematically mapping high-resolution infrared thermograms onto them, as demonstrated on walls in the Ancient Agora of Athens. This combined approach precisely localizes thermal anomalies like rising damp and material deterioration, significantly enhancing the accuracy of condition assessments and supporting informed conservation decisions.

title: Full-Spectrum LED-Driven Underwater Spectral Detection System and Its Applications
abstract: Spectral detection technology offers non-destructive, in situ, and high-speed capabilities, making it widely applicable for detecting biological and chemical samples and quantifying their concentrations. Water resources, essential to life on Earth, are widely distributed across the planet. The application of spectral technology to underwater environments is useful for wide-area water resource monitoring. Although spectral detection technology is well-established, its underwater application presents challenges, including waterproof housing design, power supply, and data transmission, which limit widespread application of underwater spectral detection. Furthermore, underwater spectral detection necessitates the development of compatible computational methods for sample classification or regression analysis. Focusing on underwater spectral detection, this work involved the construction of a suitable hardware system. A compact spectrometer and LEDs (400 nm–800 nm) were employed as the detection and light source modules, respectively, resulting in a compact system architecture. Extensive tests confirmed that the miniaturized design-maintained system performance. Further, this study addressed the estimation of total phosphorus (TP) concentration in water using spectral data. Samples with varying TP concentrations were prepared and calibrated against standard detection instruments. Subsequently, classification algorithms applied to the acquired spectral data enabled the in situ underwater determination of TP concentration in these samples. This work demonstrates the feasibility of underwater spectral detection for future in situ, high-speed monitoring of aquatic biochemical indicators. In the future, after adding UV LED light source, more water quality parameter information can be obtained.
authors: Yunfei Li, Jun Wei, Shaohua Cheng, Tao Yu, Hong Zhao, Guancheng Li, Fuhong Cai
summary: Spectral detection offers a non-destructive method for monitoring biological and chemical samples, but its underwater application faces significant challenges related to hardware, power, data transmission, and computational methods. This study addressed these issues by constructing a compact hardware system, integrating a miniaturized spectrometer and LEDs, and developing compatible classification algorithms. The system successfully demonstrated the in situ underwater estimation of total phosphorus concentration in water samples. This work thus proves the feasibility of using underwater spectral detection for future rapid, on-site monitoring of aquatic biochemical indicators.

title: Self-Powered Triboelectric Vibration Sensor for Non-Destructive Density Evaluation of Metal 3D-Printed Parts
abstract: <title>Abstract</title> In this study, a self-powered triboelectric vibration sensor (TVS) was designed and fabricated to enable non-destructive evaluation of the density of metal 3D-printed specimens. The developed TVS employed a rigid glass substrate combined with an aluminum friction electrode and an electrospun PVDF-TrFE nanofiber layer, which together established a contact-separation-based triboelectric conversion mechanism. The nanofiber layer, characterized by its high porosity and flexibility, was engineered to increase the effective contact area and enhance the sensing sensitivity, while also functioning as a structural cushion to improve mechanical durability.Using this sensor, the vibration attenuation characteristics of metal 3D-printed specimens with different densities (10%, 60%, and 100%) were measured. Under test conditions of 200 Hz frequency and 50 µm amplitude, the results demonstrated a clear linear correlation between the specimen density and the degree of vibration attenuation. The relationship between the TVS output voltage and specimen density was quantified with a coefficient of determination (R²) of 0.984, confirming the feasibility of accurate density estimation.These findings indicate that the triboelectric sensor can be extended beyond conventional energy harvesting applications into a practical sensing platform capable of industrial use in structural health monitoring and quality assessment of 3D-printed components. Furthermore, this study provides a concrete example of how TENG technology can contribute to broader commercialization and adoption by demonstrating low-cost, battery-free, and lightweight advantages that enable deployment across diverse industrial settings.
authors: Young Won Kim, Jiyong Park
summary: This study developed a self-powered triboelectric vibration sensor (TVS) for non-destructive evaluation of metal 3D-printed specimen density. The sensor employs a contact-separation triboelectric mechanism, utilizing an electrospun PVDF-TrFE nanofiber layer to enhance sensitivity and mechanical durability. Experiments demonstrated a clear linear correlation (R² = 0.984) between the TVS output voltage and specimen density, enabling accurate density estimation. These findings suggest the TVS is a practical, low-cost, and battery-free platform suitable for industrial structural health monitoring and quality assessment of 3D-printed components.

title: Acoustic Emission Monitoring of Jacketed Concrete Beams &amp; Columns
abstract: This paper presents the application of real-time Acoustic Emission (AE) monitoring and post-test analysis in jacketed concrete members representing typical reinforced concrete beams and columns in buildings. The real-time AE monitoring focused on cumulative AE activity, historic event plots, and event localization using 2D and 3D algorithms to correlate AE signals with visually observed damage. Post-processing analyses were performed to evaluate the evolution of damage in relation to applied loading. The potential use of Moment Tensor analysis, integrated with the NOESIS neural network and pattern recognition software, is explored to enhance damage characterization. AE data and case studies from previous research projects are presented, demonstrating the correlation between AE event localization and observed crack patterns. Both as-built and retrofitted members were subjected to static and fatigue loading scenarios simulating seismic conditions, with AE monitoring conducted throughout. In all cases, AE monitoring successfully detected damage initiation and progression in real time, enabling characterization of crack development. Comparative analyses between original and jacketed members highlight the effectiveness of jacketing as a retrofitting technique. Overall, AE proved to be a valuable non-destructive technique for early detection, monitoring, and characterization of structural damage in reinforced concrete elements.
authors: Dimitrios Papasalouros, Athanasios Anastasopoulos, D Kourousis
summary: This paper explores the application of real-time Acoustic Emission (AE) monitoring for detecting and characterizing damage in reinforced concrete beams and columns, including retrofitted members. The study employed various AE analysis techniques, such as cumulative activity, event localization, and post-processing, while also investigating Moment Tensor analysis integrated with neural networks. AE monitoring successfully identified damage initiation and progression in real time, correlating AE events with visually observed crack patterns under static and fatigue loading. Overall, AE proved to be a valuable non-destructive technique for early damage detection and structural health monitoring, also demonstrating the effectiveness of jacketing as a retrofitting method.

title: Visible-near infrared hyperspectral imaging for non-destructive estimation of leaf nitrogen content under water-saving irrigation in protected tomato cultivation
abstract: Accurate estimation of leaf nitrogen content (LNC) is critical for optimizing fertilization strategies in greenhouse tomato production. This study developed a robust hyperspectral-based framework for non-destructive LNC prediction by combining advanced spectral preprocessing, feature selection, and machine learning. Hyperspectral reflectance data were collected across five nitrogen and irrigation treatments over key growth stages. Signal quality was enhanced through Savitzky–Golay smoothing (SG) and Standard Normal Variate normalization (SNV). Key nitrogen-sensitive wavelengths—centered around 725 nm and 730 - 780 nm—were identified using Competitive Adaptive Reweighted Sampling (CARS) and Principal Component Analysis (PCA). Four predictive models were compared, among which a hybrid Stacked Autoencoder–Feedforward Neural Network (SAE-FNN) achieved the highest accuracy (test R² = 0.77, RPD = 2.06), effectively capturing nonlinear spectral–nitrogen interactions. In contrast, Support Vector Machine (SVM) exhibited overfitting and Partial Least Squares Method (PLSR) underperformed due to its linear constraints. These results underscore the potential of integrating hyperspectral sensing with deep learning for intelligent nitrogen monitoring in controlled-environment agriculture.
authors: Caixia Hu, Tingting Zhao, Yingying Duan, Yungui Zhang, Xinxiu Wang, Jie Li, Guilong Zhang
summary: This study developed a non-destructive hyperspectral framework to accurately estimate leaf nitrogen content (LNC) in greenhouse tomatoes, crucial for optimizing fertilization strategies. The methodology involved advanced spectral preprocessing and identified key nitrogen-sensitive wavelengths around 725 nm and 730-780 nm through feature selection. Among various machine learning models, a hybrid Stacked Autoencoder–Feedforward Neural Network (SAE-FNN) achieved the highest accuracy (test R² = 0.77), effectively capturing complex nonlinear spectral–nitrogen interactions. These results underscore the significant potential of integrating hyperspectral sensing with deep learning for intelligent nitrogen monitoring in controlled-environment agriculture.

title: Geomechanical properties evaluation of Mauddud formation based on experimental measurements and well log data
abstract: Mauddud formation is one of the most prominent formations in Northeastern Iraq due to its significant hydrocarbon reserves, making accurate geomechanical characterization essential for safe drilling operations and informed development planning. This study constructs a calibrated post-drill one dimensional mechanical earth model (1D-MEM) for selected wells, levering Techlog software to integrate rock mechanical data, image logs, multi-arm caliper measurements, conventional well logs, drilling reports, and core analyses. The methodology provides a detailed workflow for estimating geomechanical properties from log and image analysis to model calibration. Validation of the 1-D MEM performed through cross-comparison with direct measurements, ensuring the reliability of the predicted stress and strength profile. Laboratory and field data including pore pressure measurements using DST method, destructive and non-destructive mechanical tests, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), thin section test (TS), X-ray diffraction test (XRD), and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) have all been used for analyzation and calibration process. These datasets enhance the MEM parameters and support the derivation of empirical correlation specific to the Mauddud Formation. Derived correlations include compressional-shear slowness velocity, slowness velocity- bulk density, compression slowness-unconfined compressive strength (UCS), and the Young's modulus to UCS correlation. Results show that mineralogical composition particularly porosity and calcite content have a dominant influence on formation strength with high porosity, low calcite intervals resulting in the lowest UCS values.
authors: Mohammed Almojahed F. Al-jumaili, Nagham J. Al-Ameri
summary: This study focuses on the Mauddud formation in Northeastern Iraq, a significant hydrocarbon reservoir, to provide essential geomechanical characterization for safe drilling and informed development planning. A calibrated one-dimensional Mechanical Earth Model (1D-MEM) was constructed for selected wells, integrating various data sources like well logs, image logs, drilling reports, and core analyses using Techlog software. The model's reliability was ensured through validation against direct measurements and extensive laboratory and field data, which also facilitated the derivation of formation-specific empirical correlations. Results indicate that mineralogical composition, particularly porosity and calcite content, significantly influences the formation's strength, with high porosity and low calcite intervals exhibiting the lowest unconfined compressive strength (UCS) values.

title: Seismic Risk Assessment of Existing RC Buildings in Muğla
abstract: Turkey is located in a highly seismic region and has experienced major earthquakes with substantial casualties and economic losses in the past two decades. The February 6, 2023, Mw 7.7 and 7.6 sequential earthquakes were catastrophic ones that affected eleven cities with many casualties and high economic losses. The increased financial burden would not be necessary if our building stock were in decent shape. Therefore, it is critical to assess the seismic vulnerability of existing buildings to be able to take precautions. Muğla is one of the high-seismic cities located in the western part of Türkiye. In this study, a walk-down survey method proposed by the code The Principles of Identifying Risky Buildings (RYTEIE, 2019), a simple and rapid method, is used to assess the risk levels of RC buildings in the Emirbeyazıt neighborhood of Menteşe, Muğla. 469 RC buildings are examined considering parameters such as age, number of stories, and technical deficiencies, including soft or weak stories. The performance score is calculated for each building and ranked in ascending order to decide the risk prioritization. 26 RC buildings were selected from a different range of performance scores to be able to evaluate the preliminary assessment method using the concrete compressive strength and confinement rebar searched by non-destructive testing methods. The blueprints were used to calculate the base shear capacities and assessed by a preliminary assessment method to observe the performance levels and relationship with performance score.
authors: Vesile Hatun Akansel, M. Artun Baki
summary: Turkey, a highly seismic region, frequently experiences catastrophic earthquakes that result in substantial casualties and economic losses, largely due to vulnerable building stock. This study addresses the critical need to assess seismic vulnerability by focusing on reinforced concrete (RC) buildings in Muğla, a high-seismic city. Researchers employed a rapid walk-down survey method (RYTEIE, 2019) to examine 469 RC buildings in the Emirbeyazıt neighborhood, considering factors like age, number of stories, and structural deficiencies. Performance scores were calculated for each building to prioritize risk, and a subset of 26 buildings underwent further non-destructive testing and blueprint analysis to evaluate the preliminary assessment method and its relationship with performance levels.

title: Adulteration in Herbal Medicines: A Comprehensive Review on Types, Detection, and Health Impacts
abstract: Pharmacognosy Research,2025,17,4,1116-1126.DOI:10.5530/pres.20250085Published:August 2025Type:Review ArticleAuthors:Ravjot Kaur, Tirath Choudhary, Ramandeep Kaur, Mansi Garg, Nagendra Singh Chauhan, Abhilasha Jain, and Ashish Baldi Author(s) affiliations:Ravjot Kaur1, Tirath Choudhary1, Ramandeep Kaur1, Mansi Garg1, Nagendra Singh Chauhan2, Abhilasha Jain3, Ashish Baldi1,* 1Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences & Technology, Maharaja Ranjit Singh Punjab Technical University, Bathinda, Punjab, INDIA. 2Drug Testing Laboratory Avam Anusandhan Kendra, Government Ayurvedic College Campus, GE Road, Raipur, Chhattisgarh, INDIA. 3Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Giani Zail Singh Campus College of Engineering & Technology, Maharaja Ranjit Singh Punjab Technical University, Bathinda, Punjab, INDIA. Abstract:Background: Adulteration of herbal medicines is a large-scale issue that compromises the quality, safety, and therapeutic effect of herbal drugs. It entails deliberate substitution, contamination, and incorporation of undeclared synthetic compounds, which often leads to serious adverse health effects. Objectives: This review critically examines the prevalence, character, and public health impact of herbal adulteration. It also specifies present advancements in identification methods and persistent gaps in methods and authentication. Materials and Methods: A critical literature review of world case studies, pharmacopoeial reports were taken. Emphasis was placed on the prevalence of adulteration of widely used herbal medicines. Both traditional methods of analysis (chromatographic and spectroscopic) and the newer tools, like artificial intelligence-based systems for authentication and classification, were considered. Results: Substitution adulteration is the most common, up to 70-90% in prevalent herbs like Coscinium fenestratum, Embelia ribes, and Saraca asoca. Various commercial preparations were detected to contain undeclared synthetic adulterants like corticosteroids, NSAIDs, and sildenafil. Heavy metals, microplastics, and pesticides as impurities add a triple burden of exposure, resulting in oxidative stress, endocrine disruptions, neurotoxicity, reproductive toxicity, and microbiome disruption. Though non-destructive, quick authentication techniques, most notably AI-powered image recognition and spectral analysis, are on the horizon, their application in daily quality control is still limited. Conclusion: Harmonized international regulation, more robust quality control measures, and better pharmacovigilance systems are needed urgently. Integrating interdisciplinary collaboration, building capacity, and enhancing consumer education will be key to controlling adulteration and the long-term credibility and safety of herbal medicines. Keywords:Adulteration, Artificial Intelligence, Chromatography, Herbal drugs, Machine Learning, Pharmacovigilance, Toxic effectsView:PDF (1.6 MB)
authors: Rajinder Kaur, Tirath Choudhary, Ramandeep Kaur, Manish Garg, Nagendra Singh Chauhan, Abhilasha Jain, Ashish Baldi
summary: Herbal medicine adulteration is a widespread issue that compromises the quality, safety, and therapeutic effects of these drugs, often involving undeclared synthetic compounds and contaminants. This review critically examines the prevalence, character, and public health impact of such adulteration, alongside current and emerging identification methods. Findings indicate that substitution is highly common (70-90% in some herbs), and commercial preparations frequently contain undeclared synthetic adulterants and impurities like heavy metals, leading to various toxicities. The authors conclude that urgent measures, including harmonized international regulation, robust quality control, and enhanced pharmacovigilance, are essential to ensure the long-term safety and credibility of herbal medicines.

title: The application of selected tomographic imaging methods in the inspection of concrete bridges
abstract: Majority of non-destructive testing (NDT) methodologies necessitate access to only one side of the structure. Due to factors such as wave absorption or reflection by the test object, it is necessary to position the transmitter and receiver on different sides of the test surface. This particular investigative modality is designated as tomography. The article reviews the literature on the use of tomography for the inspection of concrete structures, and presents the results of research conducted on the use of GPR in tomographic mode on a bridge support. It is concluded that GPR in tomographic mode is well suited for mapping larger areas with varying concrete quality. Conversely, radiography is particularly well suited to point measurements and is not limited by the influence of dense reinforcement mesh. It has been determined that when employing a suitable radiation source, the risk to human health when utilising this method is negligible. The article examines X-ray tomography and ground-penetrating radar (GPR) techniques, both employing tomographic imaging and requiring access to at least two sides of the structure. It aims to compare the two methods in terms of accuracy and data acquisition, based on the author’s experimental results and evidence from international literature.
authors: Łukasz Topczewski
summary: This article reviews non-destructive testing (NDT) tomography for inspecting concrete structures, focusing on methods that require access to multiple sides. It specifically examines and compares X-ray tomography (radiography) and ground-penetrating radar (GPR) in tomographic mode, evaluating their accuracy and data acquisition based on literature and the author's experimental results. The research indicates that GPR tomography is well-suited for mapping large areas with varying concrete quality. Conversely, radiography excels at precise point measurements and is not hindered by dense reinforcement, with negligible health risks when using an appropriate radiation source.

title: Comparative Analysis of Compressive Strength of Natural and Brick Aggregate Concrete
abstract: An experimental study had been conducted to study of substituting natural coarse aggregate with different proportions of crushed brick aggregate impacts the compressive strength of concrete. The study aims to compare the compressive strength of nominal mixed M15, M20 and M25 grade concrete by replacing stone aggregate with crushed bricks aggregate with volumetric replacement (0%,25%,50%,75% and 100%) also find the relation between the results of NDT and destructive test. A total of 45 number of concrete mixes specimens are casted with and without crushed bricks. These specimens were tested at 28 days for compressive strength. In this paper experimental research has been carried out involving both destructive with universal testing machine and non-destructive test with rebound hammer test. The result indicated that using crushed bricks reduces the strength of concrete. The research emphasizes reusing bricks which reduces waste and enhance recourse recycling and conservation.
authors: A.K. Mishra S.Khadka, Paribesh Timisina, Sundar Adhikari
summary: This experimental study investigated the impact of replacing natural coarse aggregate with varying proportions of crushed brick aggregate on the compressive strength of M15, M20, and M25 grade concrete. Researchers cast 45 concrete mixes, testing them at 28 days using both destructive (UTM) and non-destructive (rebound hammer) methods, also aiming to correlate these test results. The findings indicated that using crushed bricks reduces concrete strength. However, the research emphasizes the environmental benefits of reusing bricks for waste reduction and resource conservation.

title: In Situ Monitoring of the Martensitic Transformation Induced by Plasticity in a Stainless Steel
abstract: This study aims to develop and evaluate NDT methods for monitoring strain-induced martensitic transformation in AISI 304L stainless steel.
authors: W Jbara, A Koster, M Rambaudon, L Daniel… - Experimental …, 2025 - Springer
summary: This study aims to develop and evaluate non-destructive testing (NDT) methods. These methods are specifically designed to monitor strain-induced martensitic transformation. The research focuses on this phenomenon as it occurs in AISI 304L stainless steel.

title: Heterostructure engineering of rod-like Bi2S3/Bi2Se3 composites for high-sensitivity direct X-ray detection with ultra-low detection limit
abstract:
Abstract
Direct X-ray detection technology, enabled by its rapid response, high special resolution and simple system configuration, has witnessed widespread applications in medical imaging, industrial non-destructive testing and scientific research. This drives the need for high-performance X-ray detection materials aiming for high sensitivity and low detection limits. Sulfides face significant challenges in X-ray detection performance due to the low atomic number of sulfur, intrinsic defects such as sulfur vacancies, and surface oxidation susceptibility. Herein, a series of rod-like clustered Bi2S3/Bi2Se3 composites with tunable S/Se molar ratios were synthesized via a facile hydrothermal method. Precise control of Se incorporation effectively modulated the morphology of nanorod-assembled Bi2S3 clusters, enhancing their structural and optoelectronic properties. Notably, the optimized Bi2S3-8% Se composite exhibited enlarged dimensions and denser nanorod clusters, leading to significantly improved X-ray detection performance. Under 40 kV X-ray irradiation, detectors based on Bi2S3-8% Se pellets achieved a remarkable sensitivity of 1025.37 μC·Gyair-1·cm-2, representing 3.5 times higher than pure Bi2S3. Furthermore, its detection limit was drastically reduced to 130 nGyair·s-1. The enhanced performance is attributed to the formation of Bi2S3/Bi2Se3 heterostructures, which facilitate efficient charge separation and transport, thereby boosting X-ray photoconversion efficiency. These findings highlight the potential of Bi2S3/Bi2Se3 composites as high-performance direct X-ray detectors, offering a promising strategy for developing advanced radiation detection materials.
authors: B Li, Q Ma, P Gao, H Zhang, X Yang, M Song… - New Journal of …, 2025 - pubs.rsc.org
summary: This study addresses the need for high-performance X-ray detection materials, noting the limitations of conventional sulfides. Researchers synthesized rod-like clustered Bi2S3/Bi2Se3 composites with tunable S/Se ratios using a hydrothermal method. The optimized Bi2S3-8% Se composite demonstrated significantly improved X-ray detection performance, achieving 3.5 times higher sensitivity and a drastically reduced detection limit compared to pure Bi2S3. This enhanced performance is attributed to the formation of Bi2S3/Bi2Se3 heterostructures, which facilitate efficient charge separation and transport, highlighting their potential for advanced direct X-ray detectors.

розподільних електричних мережах. Проаналізовано основні чинники, що впливають на стан ізоляції кабелів, та зосереджено увагу на основних типах ушкоджень, які виникають у процесі експлуатації. Окрему увагу приділено необхідності впровадження систем технічної діагностики та методів неруйнівного контролю, які дозволяють своєчасно виявити дефекти, оцінити залишковий ресурс та забезпечити безперервний моніторинг стану ізоляції. summary: This abstract analyzes methods for monitoring the condition of power cable lines in distribution electrical networks, examining factors affecting insulation and common operational damage. It emphasizes the critical need for implementing technical diagnostics and non-destructive testing (NDT) systems. These systems enable timely defect detection, residual life assessment, and continuous insulation monitoring, with a focus on approaches that do not disrupt network operation. The paper concludes by highlighting the importance of further research to improve diagnostic techniques and predict cable line reliability.
